faq.label: FAQ
faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about fxTunnel.

items.a: fxTunnel is a reverse tunneling service that exposes your local servers to the internet via HTTP subdomains, TCP ports, or UDP ports. It works like ngrok but with a desktop GUI client, free custom subdomains, and no session timeouts.

items.q: What is the best free alternative to ngrok?
items.a: fxTunnel offers free custom subdomains, unlimited bandwidth, no session timeout, and a desktop GUI client — features that competitors like ngrok charge for. You can use any subdomain you want on the free plan, unlike ngrok which assigns random URLs.

items.q: What tunneling service has a desktop app?
items.a: fxTunnel is the only tunneling service with a native cross-platform desktop client. The GUI app runs on Windows, macOS, and Linux, letting you manage tunnels visually without using the terminal.
Yes. fxTunnel supports HTTP, TCP, and UDP protocols. UDP tunneling is useful for game servers, VoIP, DNS, and other real-time applications. Most competitors only support HTTP and TCP.

items.q: How do I test webhooks locally?
items.a: Run 'fxtunnel http 3000 --subdomain webhooks' to get a public URL like webhooks.fxtun.dev. Point your webhook provider (Stripe, GitHub, Twilio) to this URL, and all requests will be forwarded to your local server on port 3000.

items.q: Can I use custom domains with fxTunnel?
items.a: Yes. On paid plans you can bring your own domain with automatic HTTPS via Let's Encrypt. Set up a CNAME record for subdomains or an A record for apex domains, and fxTunnel handles SSL certificate provisioning automatically.
No. There are no bandwidth or request limits on any plan, including free. Your tunnels can handle as much traffic as needed without throttling or caps.
No. fxTunnel tunnels stay open indefinitely. Unlike ngrok's free tier which used to have 2-hour session limits, fxTunnel keeps your tunnels running 24/7 with automatic reconnection.
Yes. fxTunnel is fully self-hostable. You can run your own server on your infrastructure, giving you complete control over your tunneling setup, data, and security.

fxTunnel has a free plan with 3 tunnels and any subdomain you want. Paid plans start at $5/month for more tunnels, reserved subdomains, custom domains, and the traffic inspector. There are no hidden fees.

items.q: What's the difference between fxTunnel and Cloudflare Tunnel?
items.a: Cloudflare Tunnel only supports HTTP and requires the Cloudflare ecosystem. fxTunnel supports HTTP, TCP, and UDP, has a desktop GUI, doesn't require any ecosystem lock-in, and is self-hostable. Cloudflare Tunnel is free but limited to their platform.

items.q: How do I expose localhost to the internet?
items.a: Install the fxTunnel client, then run 'fxtunnel http 3000' to instantly get a public URL for your local server running on port 3000. No configuration needed — just one command.
Yes. All HTTP tunnels automatically get HTTPS via the server's wildcard TLS certificate. Custom domains also get automatic HTTPS through Let's Encrypt certificate provisioning.

The traffic inspector is a real-time HTTP request/response viewer built into fxTunnel. You can search, filter by method or status, and replay requests with one click — perfect for debugging webhooks and API integrations.
Yes. fxTunnel provides full bidirectional WebSocket passthrough with no additional configuration. WebSocket connections are forwarded transparently to your local server.

customDomains.title: Custom Domains

customDomains.cnameHint: Point your domain to the server using DNS records:
customDomains.dnsGuideSubdomain: For subdomains (e.g. app.example.com): create a CNAME record
customDomains.dnsGuideApex: For root domains (e.g. example.com): create an A record
customDomains.dnsGuideSteps:
1. Go to your domain registrar's DNS settings
2. Add a new record (CNAME or A)
3. Wait for DNS propagation (up to 24h)
4. Click Verify
customDomains.reserveFirstHint: A custom domain is linked to a reserved subdomain. If you don't have one yet — create it.
customDomains.verifySuccess: Domain verified! TLS certificate will be obtained shortly.

tokens.title: Access Keys
tokens.subtitle: Keys for connecting CLI and GUI clients to the server
tokens.whatIsToken: An access key is a password for the client app. It lets you connect to the server without entering your login and password.
tokens.howToUseStep1: Create a key and copy it
tokens.howToUseStep2: In CLI run: fxtunnel login --token your_key
tokens.howToUseStep3: Or paste the key into the Token field in the GUI client
tokens.createHint: A key grants access to the server on your behalf. Create a separate key for each device or project.
tokens.tokenNameHint: So you remember what this key is for. E.g. "Work laptop" or "CI/CD".
tokens.allowedSubdomainsHint: Which subdomains this key can use. Asterisk * means any. You can use patterns: dev-*, test-*.
tokens.maxTunnelsHint: How many tunnels can be opened at the same time with this key.
tokens.noTokens: You don't have any access keys yet
tokens.noTokensHint: Create your first key to connect the client to the server without entering login and password.
tokens.copyWarning: Copy the key right now and save it in a safe place. After closing this window, you won't be able to see it again.
tokens.confirmDelete: Delete this key? All devices using it will lose access to the server.
